item.title: Kamchatka, Home to Russian Version of Alaska Iditarod, Frets Over Growth
item.description: The remote Russian peninsula is caught between ambitious plans to develop untapped resources like gold and oil, and efforts to preserve its natural splendor.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The annual Beringia dog sled race, which was conceived 25 years ago as Russia’s answer to the Iditarod, passes through the remote Kamchatka peninsula.

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Britain Spied to Ensure Falklands Security, Report Says
item.description: Britain spied on Argentine military and political leaders to ensure the security of the Falkland Islands from 2006 to 2011, an Argentine television channel reported on Friday, citing intelligence documents provided by Edward J. Snowden.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: TV Reports on Hostage Taking Prompt Lawsuit and an Investigation
item.description: Families of the hostages held by a gunman who killed four people in a kosher supermarket in Paris in January are suing a French broadcaster, saying its live coverage endangered the hostages’ lives.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Deports American Jailed on Spy Charges
item.description: Xue Feng, an American geologist imprisoned for more than seven years has been deported by China and has arrived home in Houston, a human rights organization said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Nuclear Plant in Iranian Desert Emerges as Flash Point in Talks
item.description: Uncertainty remained over whether Fordo, once a secret site of Tehran’s nuclear program, will be converted into a peaceful research center or instead eventually aid Iran’s pursuit of an atom bomb.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: An Iran Nuclear Deal Built on Coffee, All-Nighters and Compromise
item.description: In hashing out one of the hardest-to-negotiate arms control agreements in history, Iran and the United States took a simple approach: stay in the same hotel room until they figure out how to get along.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Wendy Sherman, the leader of the American negotiating team, in Switzerland on Thursday.

item.title: A U.S. Concession to Reality in the Battle Against Islamic State
item.description: In the battle to retake Tikrit, the Iraqi military served as a go-between for two global adversaries that did not want to publicly acknowledge that they were working together.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Praying for a slain relative at the platform on the Tigris River where Islamic State fighters are believed to have killed hundreds of Iraqi soldiers last June.

item.title: Antitrust and Other Inquiries in Europe Target U.S. Tech Giants
item.description: New developments offer the latest sign that American tech giants face intensifying scrutiny in Europe that could curb their profits in the region and affect how they operate around the world.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: A commuter wearing Beats headphones in New York. European concerns focus on whether Apple may try to persuade labels to favor its new streaming service over those of rivals.

item.title: With Iran Deal in Hand, White House Makes Sales Pitch to Preserve It
item.description: The intensity of the campaign reflects the challenge President Obama faces in building support among lawmakers for an agreement that could be one of the most important American foreign policy achievements in decades.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama must convince skeptics, especially in Congress, about the agreement reached on Iran’s nuclear program.

item.title: Fates of 3 Americans Held in Iran Remain Hazy Despite Diplomatic Progress
item.description: The families of three Americans of Iranian descent who are incarcerated in Iran have been hoping that a nuclear accord will prompt Iran to release them.
item.category: American Center for Law and Justice
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Main Syria-Jordan Crossing Under Insurgent Assault
item.description: The power struggle at a crucial gateway, which remains closed and chaotic, is part of the latest cross-border spillover from Syria’s four-year war.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.media:description: A fire raged Friday in a bombed-out section of the northern Syrian city of Idlib, which has fallen out of control of the government.

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: Opposition Party Leader Is Considering an Election Boycott
item.description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Myanmar opposition leader, said on Friday that boycotting an upcoming election was an “option” if a military-drafted Constitution remained unchanged.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Study Finds Mexican Troops Did Not Stem Drug-War Killings
item.description: A statistical analysis of homicide rates in 18 regions of Mexico confirms that the arrival of soldiers failed to reduce the number of murders in 16 of those areas.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Bulgaria: Officials Tackle Corruption
item.description: Bulgaria announced plans on Friday to form a special unit to investigate high-level corruption, following a neighbor, Romania, in seeking to shed an image as one of Europe’s most corrupt states.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Arab World Adjusts to Shift in U.S.-Iran Relations
item.description: While Tehran and its clients celebrate the nuclear deal, Saudi Arabia and its allies are determined to push back against Iranian influence.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: President Obama, left, with King Salman of Saudi Arabia and Secretary of State John Kerry in Riyadh in January after the death of King Abdullah.

item.title: Open Source: Bahrain Arrests Rights Activist Over Tweets About Torture
item.description: One of Bahrain’s most prominent human rights activists, Nabeel Rajab, was arrested for posting critical remarks about the government on Twitter.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Affiliate of Al Qaeda Seizes Major Yemeni City, Driving Out the Military
item.description: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula stormed Al Mukalla while Yemen’s attention has been on the escalating fighting with Houthi rebels.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: French Bill Barring Ultrathin Models Clears a Hurdle
item.description: Controversial new measures to prohibit modeling agencies from hiring dangerously thin models came closer to passage Friday.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Accelerated During Descent, Data From 2nd Recorder Shows
item.description: Data showed that Andreas Lubitz used the autopilot to direct the plane to descend to 100 feet, then repeatedly increased the speed.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: French rescue workers at the crash site of the Germanwings plane near Seyne-les-Alpes, France.

item.title: News Analysis: Israeli Response to Iran Nuclear Deal Could Have Broader Implications
item.description: Though Israeli and American officials have long denied any linkage between the Iranian and Palestinian issues, the two are playing out simultaneously.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
